Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task has generous buffer time and others can proceed without it for a while.
Situation2: They coordinate closely with contractors to keep the construction schedule on track.
Story: I sat at my desk, staring at the email from my project manager reminding me about the design review I was supposed to finish by Friday. As a colleague, I knew the task wasn’t urgent—there was plenty of buffer time, and the rest of the team could move forward without my input for now. But as the architect, I was also juggling calls from the contractor, who needed my immediate feedback on a structural detail to avoid holding up the construction crew. The pressure to keep the project moving was intense; any delay on my part could throw off the entire schedule. I felt torn—if I focused on the contractor, I’d be letting my team down by not meeting the internal deadline. But if I prioritized the team’s task, I risked stalling the build and damaging my reputation for efficiency. My mind raced, weighing the expectations from both sides, feeling the tension tighten in my chest as I tried to decide which role to serve first.
